content.name: calc
content.title: Calculation
content.details:
Module for calculations and processing of numeric values.

These definitions are part of the calc module and not imported by default. In addition to the functions listed below, the calc module also defines the constants pi, tau, e, and inf.

functions.name: abs
functions.title: Absolute
functions.oneliner: Calculates the absolute value of a numeric value.

details.content: Calculates the absolute value of a numeric value.

content.body:
#calc.abs(-5) \
#calc.abs(5pt - 2cm) \
#calc.abs(2fr) \
#calc.abs(decimal("-342.440"))

details.content: The value whose absolute value to calculate.

functions.name: pow
functions.title: Power
functions.oneliner: Raises a value to some exponent.

details.content: Raises a value to some exponent.

content.body:
#calc.pow(2, 3) \
#calc.pow(decimal("2.5"), 2)

details.content:
The base of the power.

If this is a decimal, the exponent can only be an integer.
The exponent of the power.

functions.name: exp
functions.title: Exponential
functions.oneliner: Raises a value to some exponent of e.

details.content: Raises a value to some exponent of e.

content.body: #calc.exp(1)

details.content: The exponent of the power.

functions.name: sqrt
functions.title: Square Root
functions.oneliner: Calculates the square root of a number.

details.content: Calculates the square root of a number.

content.body:
#calc.sqrt(16) \
#calc.sqrt(2.5)

details.content: The number whose square root to calculate. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: root
functions.title: Root
functions.oneliner: Calculates the real nth root of a number.

details.content:
Calculates the real nth root of a number.

If the number is negative, then n must be odd.

content.body:
#calc.root(16.0, 4) \
#calc.root(27.0, 3)

details.content: The expression to take the root of.
Which root of the radicand to take.

functions.name: sin
functions.title: Sine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the sine of an angle.

details.content:
Calculates the sine of an angle.

When called with an integer or a float, they will be interpreted as radians.

content.body:
#calc.sin(1.5) \
#calc.sin(90deg)

details.content: The angle whose sine to calculate.

functions.name: cos
functions.title: Cosine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the cosine of an angle.

details.content:
Calculates the cosine of an angle.

When called with an integer or a float, they will be interpreted as radians.

content.body:
#calc.cos(1.5) \
#calc.cos(90deg)

details.content: The angle whose cosine to calculate.

functions.name: tan
functions.title: Tangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the tangent of an angle.

details.content:
Calculates the tangent of an angle.

When called with an integer or a float, they will be interpreted as radians.

content.body:
#calc.tan(1.5) \
#calc.tan(90deg)

details.content: The angle whose tangent to calculate.

functions.name: asin
functions.title: Arcsine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the arcsine of a number.

details.content: Calculates the arcsine of a number.

content.body:
#calc.asin(0) \
#calc.asin(1)

details.content: The number whose arcsine to calculate. Must be between -1 and 1.

functions.name: acos
functions.title: Arccosine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the arccosine of a number.

details.content: Calculates the arccosine of a number.

content.body:
#calc.acos(0) \
#calc.acos(1)

details.content: The number whose arccosine to calculate. Must be between -1 and 1.

functions.name: atan
functions.title: Arctangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the arctangent of a number.

details.content: Calculates the arctangent of a number.

content.body:
#calc.atan(0) \
#calc.atan(1)

details.content: The number whose arctangent to calculate.

functions.name: atan2
functions.title: Four-quadrant Arctangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the four-quadrant arctangent of a coordinate.

details.content:
Calculates the four-quadrant arctangent of a coordinate.

The arguments are (x, y), not (y, x).

content.body:
#calc.atan2(1, 1) \
#calc.atan2(-2, -3)

details.content: The X coordinate.
The Y coordinate.

functions.name: sinh
functions.title: Hyperbolic Sine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the hyperbolic sine of a hyperbolic angle.

details.content: Calculates the hyperbolic sine of a hyperbolic angle.

content.body:
#calc.sinh(0) \
#calc.sinh(1.5)

details.content: The hyperbolic angle whose hyperbolic sine to calculate.

functions.name: cosh
functions.title: Hyperbolic Cosine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the hyperbolic cosine of a hyperbolic angle.

details.content: Calculates the hyperbolic cosine of a hyperbolic angle.

content.body:
#calc.cosh(0) \
#calc.cosh(1.5)

details.content: The hyperbolic angle whose hyperbolic cosine to calculate.

functions.name: tanh
functions.title: Hyperbolic Tangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the hyperbolic tangent of a hyperbolic angle.

details.content: Calculates the hyperbolic tangent of a hyperbolic angle.

content.body:
#calc.tanh(0) \
#calc.tanh(1.5)

details.content: The hyperbolic angle whose hyperbolic tangent to calculate.

functions.name: log
functions.title: Logarithm
functions.oneliner: Calculates the logarithm of a number.

details.content:
Calculates the logarithm of a number.

If the base is not specified, the logarithm is calculated in base 10.

content.body: #calc.log(100)

details.content: The number whose logarithm to calculate. Must be strictly positive.
The base of the logarithm. May not be zero.

functions.name: ln
functions.title: Natural Logarithm
functions.oneliner: Calculates the natural logarithm of a number.

details.content: Calculates the natural logarithm of a number.

content.body: #calc.ln(calc.e)

details.content: The number whose logarithm to calculate. Must be strictly positive.

functions.name: fact
functions.title: Factorial
functions.oneliner: Calculates the factorial of a number.

details.content: Calculates the factorial of a number.

content.body: #calc.fact(5)

details.content: The number whose factorial to calculate. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: perm
functions.title: Permutation
functions.oneliner: Calculates a permutation.

details.content:
Calculates a permutation.

Returns the k-permutation of n, or the number of ways to choose k items from a set of n with regard to order.

content.body:
$ "perm"(n, k) &= n!/((n - k)!) \
  "perm"(5, 3) &= #calc.perm(5, 3) $

details.content: The base number. Must be non-negative.
The number of permutations. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: binom
functions.title: Binomial
functions.oneliner: Calculates a binomial coefficient.

details.content:
Calculates a binomial coefficient.

Returns the k-combination of n, or the number of ways to choose k items from a set of n without regard to order.

content.body: #calc.binom(10, 5)

details.content: The upper coefficient. Must be non-negative.
The lower coefficient. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: gcd
functions.title: Greatest Common Divisor
functions.oneliner: Calculates the greatest common divisor of two integers.

details.content:
Calculates the greatest common divisor of two integers.

This will error if the result of integer division would be larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer.

content.body: #calc.gcd(7, 42)

details.content: The first integer.
The second integer.

functions.name: lcm
functions.title: Least Common Multiple
functions.oneliner: Calculates the least common multiple of two integers.

details.content: Calculates the least common multiple of two integers.

content.body: #calc.lcm(96, 13)

details.content: The first integer.
The second integer.

functions.name: floor
functions.title: Floor
functions.oneliner: Rounds a number down to the nearest integer.

details.content:
Rounds a number down to the nearest integer.

If the number is already an integer, it is returned unchanged.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
#calc.floor(500.1)
#assert(calc.floor(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.floor(3.14) == 3)
#assert(calc.floor(decimal("-3.14")) == -4)

details.content: The number to round down.

functions.name: ceil
functions.title: Ceil
functions.oneliner: Rounds a number up to the nearest integer.

details.content:
Rounds a number up to the nearest integer.

If the number is already an integer, it is returned unchanged.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
#calc.ceil(500.1)
#assert(calc.ceil(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.ceil(3.14) == 4)
#assert(calc.ceil(decimal("-3.14")) == -3)

details.content: The number to round up.

functions.name: trunc
functions.title: Truncate
functions.oneliner: Returns the integer part of a number.

details.content:
Returns the integer part of a number.

If the number is already an integer, it is returned unchanged.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
#calc.trunc(15.9)
#assert(calc.trunc(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.trunc(-3.7) == -3)
#assert(calc.trunc(decimal("8493.12949582390")) == 8493)

details.content: The number to truncate.

functions.name: fract
functions.title: Fractional
functions.oneliner: Returns the fractional part of a number.

details.content:
Returns the fractional part of a number.

If the number is an integer, returns 0.

content.body:
#calc.fract(-3.1)
#assert(calc.fract(3) == 0)
#assert(calc.fract(decimal("234.23949211")) == decimal("0.23949211"))

details.content: The number to truncate.

functions.name: round
functions.title: Round
functions.oneliner: Rounds a number to the nearest integer.

details.content:
Rounds a number to the nearest integer.

Half-integers are rounded away from zero.

Optionally, a number of decimal places can be specified. If negative, its absolute value will indicate the amount of significant integer digits to remove before the decimal point.

Note that this function will return the same type as the operand. That is, applying round to a float will return a float, and to a decimal, another decimal. You may explicitly convert the output of this function to an integer with int, but note that such a conversion will error if the float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum integer.

In addition, this function can error if there is an attempt to round beyond the maximum or minimum integer or decimal. If the number is a float, such an attempt will cause float.inf or -float.inf to be returned for maximum and minimum respectively.

content.body:
#calc.round(3.1415, digits: 2)
#assert(calc.round(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.round(3.14) == 3)
#assert(calc.round(3.5) == 4.0)
#assert(calc.round(3333.45, digits: -2) == 3300.0)
#assert(calc.round(-48953.45, digits: -3) == -49000.0)
#assert(calc.round(3333, digits: -2) == 3300)
#assert(calc.round(-48953, digits: -3) == -49000)
#assert(calc.round(decimal("-6.5")) == decimal("-7"))
#assert(calc.round(decimal("7.123456789"), digits: 6) == decimal("7.123457"))
#assert(calc.round(decimal("3333.45"), digits: -2) == decimal("3300"))
#assert(calc.round(decimal("-48953.45"), digits: -3) == decimal("-49000"))

details.content: The number to round.

If positive, the number of decimal places.

If negative, the number of significant integer digits that should be removed before the decimal point.

functions.name: clamp
functions.title: Clamp
functions.oneliner: Clamps a number between a minimum and maximum value.

details.content: Clamps a number between a minimum and maximum value.

content.body:
#calc.clamp(5, 0, 4)
#assert(calc.clamp(5, 0, 10) == 5)
#assert(calc.clamp(5, 6, 10) == 6)
#assert(calc.clamp(decimal("5.45"), 2, decimal("45.9")) == decimal("5.45"))
#assert(calc.clamp(decimal("5.45"), decimal("6.75"), 12) == decimal("6.75"))

details.content: The number to clamp.
The inclusive minimum value.
The inclusive maximum value.

functions.name: min
functions.title: Minimum
functions.oneliner: Determines the minimum of a sequence of values.

details.content: Determines the minimum of a sequence of values.

content.body:
#calc.min(1, -3, -5, 20, 3, 6) \
#calc.min("typst", "is", "cool")

details.content: The sequence of values from which to extract the minimum. Must not be empty.

functions.name: max
functions.title: Maximum
functions.oneliner: Determines the maximum of a sequence of values.

details.content: Determines the maximum of a sequence of values.

content.body:
#calc.max(1, -3, -5, 20, 3, 6) \
#calc.max("typst", "is", "cool")

details.content: The sequence of values from which to extract the maximum. Must not be empty.

functions.name: even
functions.title: Even
functions.oneliner: Determines whether an integer is even.

details.content: Determines whether an integer is even.

content.body:
#calc.even(4) \
#calc.even(5) \
#range(10).filter(calc.even)

details.content: The number to check for evenness.

functions.name: odd
functions.title: Odd
functions.oneliner: Determines whether an integer is odd.

details.content: Determines whether an integer is odd.

content.body:
#calc.odd(4) \
#calc.odd(5) \
#range(10).filter(calc.odd)

details.content: The number to check for oddness.

functions.name: rem
functions.title: Remainder
functions.oneliner: Calculates the remainder of two numbers.

details.content:
Calculates the remainder of two numbers.

The value calc.rem(x, y) always has the same sign as x, and is smaller in magnitude than y.

This can error if given a decimal input and the dividend is too small in magnitude compared to the divisor.

content.body:
#calc.rem(7, 3) \
#calc.rem(7, -3) \
#calc.rem(-7, 3) \
#calc.rem(-7, -3) \
#calc.rem(1.75, 0.5)

details.content: The dividend of the remainder.
The divisor of the remainder.

functions.name: div-euclid
functions.title: Euclidean Division
functions.oneliner: Performs euclidean division of two numbers.

details.content:
Performs euclidean division of two numbers.

The result of this computation is that of a division rounded to the integer n such that the dividend is greater than or equal to n times the divisor.

This can error if the resulting number is larger than the maximum value or smaller than the minimum value for its type.

content.body:
#calc.div-euclid(7, 3) \
#calc.div-euclid(7, -3) \
#calc.div-euclid(-7, 3) \
#calc.div-euclid(-7, -3) \
#calc.div-euclid(1.75, 0.5) \
#calc.div-euclid(decimal("1.75"), decimal("0.5"))

details.content: The dividend of the division.
The divisor of the division.

functions.name: rem-euclid
functions.title: Euclidean Remainder
functions.oneliner: This calculates the least nonnegative remainder of a division.

details.content:
This calculates the least nonnegative remainder of a division.

Warning: Due to a floating point round-off error, the remainder may equal the absolute value of the divisor if the dividend is much smaller in magnitude than the divisor and the dividend is negative. This only applies for floating point inputs.

In addition, this can error if given a decimal input and the dividend is too small in magnitude compared to the divisor.

content.body:
#calc.rem-euclid(7, 3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(7, -3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(-7, 3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(-7, -3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(1.75, 0.5) \
#calc.rem-euclid(decimal("1.75"), decimal("0.5"))

details.content: The dividend of the remainder.
The divisor of the remainder.

functions.name: quo
functions.title: Quotient
functions.oneliner: Calculates the quotient (floored division) of two numbers.

details.content:
Calculates the quotient (floored division) of two numbers.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting number is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
$ "quo"(a, b) &= floor(a/b) \
  "quo"(14, 5) &= #calc.quo(14, 5) \
  "quo"(3.46, 0.5) &= #calc.quo(3.46, 0.5) $

details.content: The dividend of the quotient.
The divisor of the quotient.

functions.name: norm
functions.title: ùëù-Norm
functions.oneliner: Calculates the p-norm of a sequence of values.

details.content: Calculates the p-norm of a sequence of values.

content.body:
#calc.norm(1, 2, -3, 0.5) \
#calc.norm(p: 3, 1, 2)

details.content: The p value to calculate the p-norm of.
The sequence of values from which to calculate the p-norm. Returns 0.0 if empty.
